title: 111_hr3658
content: The text chunk discusses an amendment to a joint resolution regarding the Covenant To Establish a Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands in Political Union with the United States of America. It includes changes to subparagraphs and a special rule regarding aliens. The amendment to the joint resolution includes a special rule stating that certain aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands cannot be removed from the United States for violating immigration laws until 5 years after the transition program effective date. An alien described in the rule is one who was a resident of the Commonwealth on May 8, 2008. Certain aliens in the Northern Mariana Islands, including permanent residents, immediate relatives of citizens, and parents of citizens under 21, cannot be removed from the US for violating immigration laws until 5 years after the transition program effective date. Certain alien parents in the Northern Mariana Islands are eligible for a special nonimmigrant visa, granting them all the benefits. Certain alien parents in the Northern Mariana Islands are eligible for a special nonimmigrant visa that grants them privileges similar to permanent residents, with the condition that they must reside in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. The visa remains valid until the alien's child petitions for an adjustment of status to that of a permanent resident. Certain alien parents in the Northern Mariana Islands are eligible for a special nonimmigrant visa that grants them privileges similar to permanent residents. The visa remains valid until the alien's child petitions for an adjustment of status for the parent. Alien parents in the Northern Mariana Islands are eligible for a special nonimmigrant visa that grants them privileges similar to permanent residents. The visa remains valid until the alien's child petitions for an adjustment of status for the parent. Additionally, the paragraph allows an alien who may not be removed under certain circumstances to leave the Commonwealth for a temporary absence and return with the entrance permit. The paragraph discusses amendments to employment authorization for aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, including a special rule for certain individuals to be considered authorized for employment for up to 5 years. The Secretary of Homeland Security shall require any alien in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to register on an ongoing basis starting from November 28, 2009. Initial registration must be completed by February 1, 2010. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands must provide immigration records to the Secretary for implementation of registration requirements. This does not affect existing immigration laws. The Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands must provide immigration records for registration requirements, without modifying existing immigration laws. Adjustment of status for permanent residents of the Commonwealth is addressed in Section 2. Section 6 of the Joint Resolution is amended to include an adjustment of status for permanent residents of the Commonwealth, allowing eligible aliens to receive a special nonimmigrant visa. The special nonimmigrant visa allows eligible aliens in the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands to have privileges similar to permanent residents, with the condition to reside in the Commonwealth. The visa is valid until the alien adjusts status or ceases to reside in the Commonwealth. Aliens in the Northern Mariana Islands can apply for special nonimmigrant visa status under specific conditions from January 1, 2014, to November 28, 2014. The Northern Mariana Islands Visitor Entry Program transition is outlined in Section 3. The amendments to the Consolidated Natural Resources Act of 2008 will take effect 180 days after the transition program effective date. During this period, the Secretary of Homeland Security will administer the CNMI Visitor Entry Program. The amendments to the Consolidated Natural Resources Act of 2008 will take effect 180 days after the transition program effective date, with the Secretary of Homeland Security administering the CNMI Visitor Entry Program in the Northern Mariana Islands in accordance with Commonwealth law. SEC. 703A. FAMILY-BASED IMMIGRATION FEE REDUCTION FOR RESIDENTS OF THE COMMONWEALTH. SEC. 703A. Family-Based Immigration Benefit Application and Petition Fees reduction for residents of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands with immediate relative status as of May 8, 2008. The reduction amount will be determined by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The difference in average per capita income between the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands and the United States is expressed as a percentage. Certain immigration laws do not apply to residents of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands with immediate relative status as of May 8, 2008. This section will be effective upon enactment and will expire on December 31, 2014. The table of contents for the Consolidated Natural Resources Act of 2008 is amended to include a new section effective until December 31, 2014. Section 703A of the Consolidated Natural Resources Act of 2008, regarding family-based immigration fee reduction for residents of the Commonwealth, will take effect as specified in the Act. The amendments made by this Act will generally take effect as if included in the original enactment.
